metadata.title: Analytical Detection of 9(4)-0-Acetylated Sialoglycoproteins and Gangliosides Using Influenza C Virus

affiliation.institution: Universite' Pierre et Marie Curie, C.H.U. Saint-Antoine

location.addrLine: laboratoire de la grippe, TUnite' de biochimie des anti&es, rue du Docteur

body_text.text: The unique glycoprotein of influenza C virus, designated hemagglutinin (HEF), exhibits three functions: hemagglutination, esterase activity, and fusion factor. As the virus uses 9-0-acetylated sialic acid as a high-affinity receptor determinant for attachment to cells, its binding activity was used to reveal 0-acetylated sialic acid residues after polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and transfer onto nitrocellulose sheets of proteins and thin-layer chromatography of lipids. The specificity of the binding for 0-acetylated sialoglycoconjugates was investigated.
Our results showed that influenza C virus could detect the different forms of the two murine glycophorins which are known to be 0-acetylated sialoglycoconjugates.

The virus also bound to 0-acetylated gangliosides isolated from embryonic chicken brain such as purified 0-acetylated NeuAccu(2-8)NeuAca(2-S)Neu-Ac(u(2-3)Ga1/3(1-4)Glc/3(l-l)ceramide (GT3). The esterase activity of the HEF protein of influenza C virus was used to unmask the sialic acid. After its deacetylation by the virus enzyme, the 0-acetylated GT3 was recognized by a monoclonal antibody which binds only to the nonacetylated derivative.

The results presented here show that influenza C virus is a discriminating analytical probe for identifying 0-acetylated sialoglycoconjugates directly after Western blotting of proteins and thin-layer chromatography of lipids, thus providing a new analytiCa tOO1. 0 1991 Academic Press, IUC.

' Abbreviations used: BSA, bovine serum albumin; BCIP, 5-bromo-4-chloro-3-indolyl phosphate p-toluidine salt; BSM, bovine subman-sion activities (1, 2) , uses 9-O-acetyl-N-acetylneuraminic acid (Neu5,9Ac,) as a high-affinity receptor determinant for attachment to cells (3) . The specificity of influenza C virus (INF-C) for Neu5,9Ac, has been studied mostly using either hemagglutination assays or binding of radioactively labeled virus. The virus binds to any Neu5,9Ac, regardless of the (~(2-3) or (2-6) linkage, in Gal/3( l-3/4)GalNAc or Gal/3( l-314)GlcNAc complexes (3) . There is no convincing report, dealing directly with the binding activity, which gives evidence of any other carbohydrate structure involved in the specificity of this activity. A major determinant of the cell tropism of INF-C is the expression of appropriate cell surface receptors (4) . Using chicken erythrocytes, this determinant, which contains Neu5,9Ac,, was shown to be a differentiation marker, whose expression increased after birth (5) .

The HEF protein (6) was isolated and characterized as a neuraminate 9-(4)-0-acetylesterase (7) . The enzyme seems to be highly specific for naturally occurring large compounds, whereas its activity is much less spe- 425 cific for small and artificial substrates; in addition, this enzyme can hydrolyze p-nitrophenyl acetate as well as a-naphthyl acetate. The enzymatic activity of the virus is thus a useful tool for studying natural compounds containing sialic acids or their 0-acetylated derivatives.
In the present study, INF-C is used for detecting Oacetylated sialoglycoconjugates.

After SDS-PAGE and semidry blotting for proteins and TLC for lipids, the binding activity of INF-C virus was studied. The viral esterase activity was used to unmask antigen for monoclonal antibody 18B8 specific for the ganglioside GT3. Specificity of the binding was demonstrated using alkali treatment of glycoconjugates, sialidase treatment, selective inhibitors, and by comparing binding of influenza C virus to that of Maackia amurensis agglutinin, a lectin of defined specificity (8) .

body_text.text: Binding of INF-C to transferred proteins on nitrocellulose sheets was studied using purified INF-C revealed with a monoclonal antibody directed against the A-l site of HEF proteins of INF-C.
body_text.section: Influenza C Virus Binds to Its Receptor-like Glycoproteins on Electrophoregrams

body_text.text: After electrophoresis and semidry blotting of proteins, extracted from murine and ovine ghost erythrocytes, a variety of procedures were compared for their ability to saturate nonspecific binding sites on nitrocellulose. Saturation with PT-1% BSA, even pretreated with periodate, as described previously (23) , was of poor efficacy, probably because of the high nonspecific binding of INF-C to nitrocellulose sheets. We finally used the blocking reagent purchased from Boehringer-Mannheim for saturation. Nitrocellulose sheets were then incubated with INF-C pretreated with DFP, which is an irreversible inhibitor of serine esterase. The bound virus was revealed with MAb 514, specific for HEF proteins of INF-C.
body_text.section: Influenza C Virus Binds to Its Receptor-like Glycoproteins on Electrophoregrams

body_text.text: In the case of murine EGP, as shown in Fig. lA , lane 2, INF-C recognized one major band on the migration pattern identified as one of the two murine sialoglycoproteins or glycophorins, designated as GP2. As previously described (24, 25) , glycophorins strongly aggregate in aqueous solution. The dissociation of aggregates is not complete in the presence of detergent and this explains why glycophorins exist in the form of dimers. This is the reason why the number of PAS-positive bands does not reflect the number of glycophorins following SDS-PAGE analysis. In addition, some bands are due not only to homo-and heterodimers but also to higher oligomers (26) . As shown in Fig. lA, lane 2 , four bands detected by INF-C can be identified as GPl, GP2, GP3.1, and GP3.2. GP2 and GP3 were demonstrated to be the two murine glycophorins, and GPl was described as the heterodimer of GP2 and GP3 (27) (28) (29) . GP3.1 was described as the mature complete form of the glyco- phorin GP3, and GP3.2 as an incomplete form of it (30) . As shown Fig. lA, lane 2 , staining of GP2, and GPl to a lesser extent, was much stronger than that of GP3. These data are consistent with the previous reports from Sarris and Palade cited above, showing that the majority of the 0-acetylated sialyl residues were carried by GP2 and GPl. As shown in Fig. lA, lane 1 , colloidal gold staining of proteins seemed to be the inverse of "viro-staining," since GP3, which carries a small amount of 0-acetylated sialic acid, was clearly stained by colloidal gold, whereas the major band recognized by INF-C was not stained at all. For molecular weights higher than 67,000 M,, the identification is not possible because of aggregates as discussed above. According to the reports cited above, it could be estimated that the total amount of murine 0-acetylated glycophorins put in a lane for detection with INF-C was less than 1.7 pg for the results shown GP2 and GPl could be detected by this technique when only 0.4 pg of 0-acetylated glycophorins was put in the lane (data not shown). Thus the detection is sensitive.

body_text.text: In the case of ovine EGP, the virus did not bind to any band, as shown Fig. lB, lane 2 .

body_text.text: These results are an expected illustration of the different affinities of INF-C for murine and ovine erythrocytes, as previously observed with hemagglutination experiments.

body_text.text: In the present study, hemagglutination experiments were carried out with the same batches of erythrocytes used for SDS-PAGE and blotting; the hemagglutination titers of a harvested allantoic fluid infected with INF-C were 512 and 0 HA units with murine and ovine erythrocytes, respectively, as indicated in Fig.  1 . These data show that the binding of INF-C is probably due to interaction with sialic acid rather than nonspecific interactions.

body_text.section: INF-C Virus Specifically Binds to 0-Acetylated Sialic

body_text.text: Using mouse erythrocytes, we next compared binding of INF-C with that of M. amurensis lectin, which recognizes specifically terminal cY(2-3)-linked sialic acids (8) .
body_text.section: INF-C Virus Specifically Binds to 0-Acetylated Sialic

body_text.text: The different forms of the two murine glycophorins recognized by INF-C, described above, were also detected by MAA. It was noted that GP2 was recognized by MAA as two bands, identified as GP2.1 and GP2.2, according to the previous descriptions of Sarris and Palade (30) . The treatment of the nitrocellulose sheet with NaOH, as described under Materials and Methods, to remove the acetyl groups involved in ester linkages, did not modify the binding of MAA (data not shown), suggesting that MAA is specific for sialic acids, O-acetylated or not.
body_text.section: INF-C Virus Specifically Binds to 0-Acetylated Sialic

body_text.text: As previously described, INF-C binds to Neu5,9Ac, but not to Neu5Ac on erythrocytes and cultured cells (3, 5) . As shown in Fig. 1 , the type of sialoglycoproteins recognized by INF-C exist on murine, which contain high amounts of Neu5,9Ac, (27, 31) , but not on ovine erythrocytes, which lack Neu5,9Ac, (32) . These results suggest that INF-C bound to Neu5,9Ac, on electrophoregrams. In order to verify this specificity, removal of acetyl groups was carried out using alkali treatment or viral 0-acetyl esterase activity, and competitive inhibition tests were made with characterized sialoglycoproteins OSM and BSM.
body_text.section: INF-C Virus Specifically Binds to 0-Acetylated Sialic

body_text.text: Following treatment of the nitrocellulose sheet with NaOH, as described under Materials and Methods, binding of INF-C could no longer be detected (Fig. 2B, lane  4) . This shows that the binding is alkali labile, suggesting that the structure involved in attachment of virus to proteins contains ester linkages, probably in the form of 0-acetyl residues. Moreover, before incubation with INF-C, pretreated with DFP, the nitrocellulose sheet was also submitted to untreated virus 0-acetyl esterase activity. As shown in Fig. 2B , lane 5, INF-C no longer bound to any glycoprotein. This shows that INF-C recognizes specifically 0-acetylated compounds.

body_text.text: Following treatment of the nitrocellulose sheet with the sialidase of V. cholwae, INF-C no longer bound to any glycoprotein, showing that INF-C binds to sialoglycoproteins.

body_text.text: OSM was prepared as described previously (33 GalNac, 4%; Fuca(l-2)Galj3(1-3)GalNac, 2%; and GalS (1) (2) (3) [GlcNA@(l-6)]GalNAc, 0.3%. BSM contains predominantly Neu5Gc, Neu5Ac, NeuSA&Gc, Neu!&SAc,, Neu5,7Ac,, and di-0-acetylated sialic acids (36, 37) . As shown in Fig. 2A , OSM did not inhibit INF-C binding to murine erythrocytic ghost proteins (lane 2), whereas BSM did (lane 3). Band GP3 was on the migration front. Densitometric analysis of the binding to GP2 was carried out as described under Materials and Methods. OSM inhibition was very low (6%), whereas BSM inhibited by 43%. These inhibition experiments show that BSM, but not OSM, carry carbohydrate structures detected by INF-C. This result provides further evidence that INF-C recognizes 0-acetylated sialic acid on transferred proteins.
body_text.section: INF-C Virus Specifically Binds to 0-Acetylated Sialic

body_text.text: Taken together, these data show clearly that INF-C specifically recognizes 0-acetylated sialoglycoproteins (containing predominantly Neu5,9Ac,) following transfer onto nitrocellulose.

body_text.text: The Binding Is Alkali Labile Binding of INF-C to gangliosides was investigated since these molecules are lipids which contain sialic acids, either 0-acetylated or not. After purification of gangliosides from embryonic chicken brain and separation by TLC, the chromatograms were incubated with INF-C pretreated with DFP. The virus was then revealed as described under Materials and Methods.
body_text.section: INF-C Virus Specifically Binds to 0-Acetylated Sialic

body_text.text: As shown in Fig. 3A , the iodinated virus INF-C bound to specific gangliosides, suggesting that some gangliosides of the plasma membrane of embryonic nervous cells can be receptors for the virus. When chromatographed gangliosides were exposed to ammonia vapors, in order to hydrolyze ester linkages, and then incubated with INF-C, no more binding of virus to any gangliosides was observed. The same results were obtained when virus bound to gangliosides was revealed with monoclonal antibody 514 (Fig. 3B, lane 1) . The binding of INF-C to the 0-acetylated trisialogangliosides (9-Oacetylated GT3) purified from lo-day embryonic chicken brain (ll), Fig. 3B , lane 2, confirms these data. This doublet, which probably differs in the ceramides, is present in the chicken brain extract. It is no longer recognized by the virus after treatment by ammonia vapors.
body_text.section: INF-C Virus Specifically Binds to 0-Acetylated Sialic

body_text.text: 0-acetylated GT3 is also recognized by the monoclonal antibody A2B5, specific for 0-acetylated and non-0-acetylated trisialogangliosides (11) (Fig. 3C ), but it is not recognized by the monoclonal antibody 18B8, specific for non-0-acetylated trisialogangliosides (10) (Fig.  3C ). This non-0-acetylated GT3 present in chicken brain extracts and as a contaminant of the preparation of the 0-acetylated derivative is not recognized by INF-C (Fig. 3B, lanes 1 and 2) . This result suggests that the gangliosides, which are receptors for the virus, are alkali labile and probably contain 0-acetylated sialic acid residues.

body_text.section: INF-C Virus Esterase Activity Unmasks Epitopes for

body_text.text: In addition to analyzing binding of INF-C to sialoglycoconjugates, we also took advantage of its esterase activity specific for 0-acetylated sialic acids to reveal cryptic antigens detected by monoclonal antibody specific for GT3. This makes the viral protein a tool for analyzing the effects of acetylation in recognition phenomena of sialoglycoconjugates. Incubations of glycolipids were carried out with virus whose enzymatic activity had not been inhibited (no preincubation with DFP). The deacetylated sialic acid residues were then revealed by incubation of gangliosides with the monoclonal antibody 18B8, which is specific for nonacetylated trisialogangliosides (10,ll).
body_text.section: INF-C Virus Esterase Activity Unmasks Epitopes for

body_text.text: The incubation of chromatographed gangliosides with the virus revealed a cryptic antigen recognized by the monoclonal antibody 18B8, specific for the trisialoganglioside GT3 (Fig. 4C, lane 2) , which was not detected with untreated gangliosides (Fig. 4A ). Since viral treatment had been performed after chromatographic migration, the unmasked GT3 detected by 18B8 appeared where 0-acetylated GT3 had previously migrated. In addition, inhibition of viral e&erase activity with DFP inhibited the appearance of the antigen recognized by MAb 18B8 (Fig. 4B) . Since monoclonal anti-body recognized specifically the non-0-acetylated trisialyl structure found in the ganglioside GT3, this suggests that active viral esterase has unmasked the sialyl group, now recognized by the antibody.
body_text.section: INF-C Virus Esterase Activity Unmasks Epitopes for

body_text.text: In this report, in order to demonstrate that INF-C virus can be used as a probe to identify 0-acetylated sialoglycoconjugates, we used cellular material known to contain high amounts of 0-acetylated sialic acid. Mouse erythrocytes, whose sialic acid is 50-60% O-acetylated, provided receptor-like glycoproteins. Embryo chicken brain provided a receptor-like glycolipid mixture, rich in 0-acetylated gangliosides. As proposed by Muchmore and Varki (38) , who suggested that hemagglutination and receptor-destroying enzyme activities do not share the same binding site of HEF, we used selective inactivation of the viral e&erase activity by DFP to prevent virus detachment.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: Using "viro-blotting," we could demonstrate that INF-C bound to glycoproteins of murine erythrocytes but not to those of ovine red blood cells. The former are known to contain 9-0-acetylated sialic acid. The failure to recognize ovine sialoglycoproteins was consistent with the lack of hemagglutination by INF-C. In order to verify that the specificity of binding of INF-C was preserved on electrophoregrams, it was shown that INF-C bound to some but not all proteins. The major glycoprotein recognized by INF-C in mouse EGP was identified as the more 0-acetylated murine glycophorin (27) . This protein was also detected by MAA, which is specific for sialic acids. Alkali, 0-acetyl e&erase, sialidase treatments, and inhibition experiments supported the expected specificity of INF-C for 0-acetylated sialic acids.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: INF-C also binds to gangliosides purified from embryonic chicken brain. Viro-staining experiments show that INF-C binds to specific gangliosides which contain alkali-labile structures. The virus binds to the purified 0-acetylated GT3, but not to GT3, as expected. These experiments suggest that 0-acetylated gangliosides of the cell membrane can be receptors for INF-C, as well as substrates for its esterase which transformed O-acetylated GT3 into GT3.
body_text.section: DISCUSSION

body_text.text: The technique using INF-C described in this report appears to be a sensitive test for the detection of O-acetylated sialic acid. INF-C is not just a probe, it also provides a biochemical tool for studying the acetylation of sialic acid. Such a tool, with two different and specific activities, can be valuable in studying the occurrence and the localization of 0-acetylated sialic acids on glycoconjugate mixtures after their electrophoretic and chromatographic separation. INF-C can also help to study the carbohydrate specificity of monoclonal antibodies.

back_matter.text: In addition to qualitative data, the technique using staining with INF-C and assisted by computed image analysis can provide a semiquantitative tool for comparison of content of 0-acetylated sialoglycoconjugates in various cells extracts.The technique reported here could be further extended in order to use INF-C as in in situ probe on histological slides. The applications of such techniques in our laboratories for studying the occurrence of 0-acetylated sialic acids in various cell lines and in some tissues, such as chicken cerebellum, are in progress, since preliminary experiments showed that INF-C might be neurotropic in experimentally infected chicken embryos. The biological importance of acetylation of sialic acids is poorly understood.The occurrence of O-acetylated sialic acids on red blood cells can vary not only with the animal species but also with the age of the animal, as was demonstrated for chicken erythrocytes (5). 0-acetylation of disialoganglioside GD3 by human melanoma cells was shown to provide a potential tumor-specific antigen (39) . INF-C has been used in the past for studying virus receptors: the major receptor for human coronaviruses OC43 and E229 was shown to be O-acetylated sialic acids by comparison with those of INF-C (40) . The acetylation of sialoglycoconjugates should interfere with different processes, such as cell maturation; cell recognition, probably with immunological implications; cell differentiation and dedifferentiation; and virus-cell interactions.The use of both binding and esterase activity could provide a better understanding of the biological roles played by 0-acetylated sialic acids.
